courses.name: Topics in Architectural Studies - Humanities
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in architectural studies. Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester. May be repeated for credit up to 6 credit hours.

courses.name: Visual Design
courses.description: Design study as an introduction to basic design and visual composition with application to creating two- and three-dimensional abstract and /or functional design work. Studio exercises expressed through drawings and abstract models, using various media.

courses.name: Architectural Drafting and Working Drawings
courses.description: Beginning drafting including equipment and materials; lettering; floor plans, sections, elevations; orthographic and axonometric drawings; working drawings; and details.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Environmental Design
courses.description: Survey of the architectural environment emphasizing design fundamentals such as use, aesthetics, stability of structures and human relationships with places and time.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Environmental Design - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Survey of the architectural environment emphasizing design fundamentals such as use, aesthetics, stability of structures and human relationships with places and time.

courses.name: Topics in Architectural Studies - Humanities
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in architectural studies. Particular topic and earnable credit may very by semester. May be repeated for credit up to 6 credit hours.

courses.name: Problems in Architectural Studies
courses.description: Supervised independent work.

courses.name: Understanding Architecture and the American City
courses.description: Multifaceted introduction to the architectural and social roots of urban form in the U. S.: historic precedents from around the world; growth, decline and revival of cities; rise of suburbia; tradition and transformation in campus communities; continuing housing challenges; sustainable design and the future of urbanism. Explores a diverse range of opportunities to improve communities available to professionals and general public.

courses.name: Understanding Visualization for Animated Films
courses.description: Provides a critical overview of design and visualization techniques in animated film making. Emphasizes the role of built environment and spatial design features.

courses.name: Introduction to CAD
courses.description: Introduction to computer-aided drafting and design with AutoCad software. Emphasis will be placed on development of skills and problem solving related to the professions of environmental and interior design.

courses.name: Design Communication I
courses.description: Beginning studio course in techniques and conventions of graphic communication as an aid in the design process for interior designers.

courses.name: Building Systems
courses.description: Integrated building systems: structure, construction, technology, comfort; including voice-data communication, safety, floor, wall, ceiling, mechanical, electrical, and plumbing systems; and project estimating.

courses.name: Introduction to Building Systems Laboratory
courses.description: Building system renovations, materials, processes, finishes, and applications testing: furniture design, fabrication, finishing, lighting, concrete and masonry, wood and steel light framing construction, and mock-up fabrication and testing. All equipment training and safety is covered in this introductory course.

courses.name: Advanced Building Systems Lab
courses.description: Advanced exposure to building system renovations, materials, processes, finishes, and applications testing: furniture design, fabrication, finishing, lighting, concrete and masonry, wood and steel light framing construction, and mock-up fabrication and testing. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Sustainable Building Design Fundamentals
courses.description: Environmental concerns addressed by green building design practices for consumers and owners of homes and businesses. Overview of how green buildings improve prospects for ecology, economy, social equity, and human health. Hands-on lab experiments reference national performance standards for decision making in sustainable building projects. Emphasis on energy and water use, sustainable sites, environmentally friendly building products, indoor air quality, and design for sustainable behaviors.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: People, Places and Design
courses.description: Understanding human behavior and interaction with environments; the influence of architectural design on built places. Practical application for design.

courses.name: Studio I
courses.description: Application of basic design and composition to built form. Studio exercises in two and three dimensions using various media relating to usable spaces. Formation of design concept, development of form and space, and application in built environment.

courses.name: Color and Light
courses.description: The theory, application, and specification of color and light for interior and architectural design.  Includes assigned lab exercises for color and light portfolio.

courses.name: Studio II
courses.description: Application of basic design principles to built forms and functional spaces. Identification and manipulation of elements of design, understanding spatial relationships between human body and spatial enclosures related to built forms. Spatial organization and familiarity with role of immediate context.

courses.name: Advanced Design Communication Using BIM
courses.description: Advanced course in techniques and conventions of computer aided design (CAD) and Building Information Modeling (BIM) for contemporary design process.

courses.name: Design Resource Management
courses.description: Field experience (5 hours per week) in organization and management of resources used by interior designers, including references, product information, and samples of materials and finishes.

courses.name: Environmental Analysis
courses.description: Discover through analytical methods of primary organizational factors which operate in a building and reveal the preoccupations of designer.  Analytical approach investigates design principles by means of dissection.

courses.name: Environmental Analysis - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Discover through analytical methods of primary organizational factors which operate in a building and reveal the preoccupations of designer.  Analytical approach investigates design principles by means of dissection.

courses.name: Human Factors Programming
courses.description: Design Programming for Human Factors using a Case Study.

courses.name: Human Factors Programming - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Design Programming for Human Factors using a Case Study.

courses.name: Topics in Architectural Studies
courses.description: Selected current topics in field of interest.

courses.name: Problems in Architectural Studies
courses.description: Supervised independent work.

courses.name: Computer Graphic Application for Design I
courses.description: Applications of computer graphics for design and art; includes visualization, animation and creative development. May repeat up to 12 credit hours maximum.

courses.name: Materials, Methods and Products
courses.description: Inherent qualities of materials used in the design of interior environments. Manufacturing, application, and installation methods. Focus on environmentally sensitive materials.

courses.name: Sustainable Technologies and Systems
courses.description: An in-depth study of ecologically-sensitive and energy-efficient strategies used in building and interiors.

courses.name: Compliance and Specifications
courses.description: Application of laws, codes, regulations, standards in specifying for life safety, barrier-free and universal design, lighting, human factors, and contract documents.

courses.name: Recent Trends in Digital Media I
courses.description: Recent Trends in Digital Media I

courses.name: Study Abroad in Architectural History
courses.description: Discovery of historic architecture through on-site tour of timeless cities and places.  May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: History of the Designed Environment after 1750
courses.description: An in-depth study of the designed environment, including housing, interiors, and furniture of the major historical periods from the Industrial Revolution to today.

courses.name: Guiding Design with Historic Preservation
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ARCHST 7430). Approaches to historic preservation; historic roots of architecture and interiors; regulations and design guidelines governing intervention; assessing significance of historic properties.
courses.recommendation: American History or Government, or Art History

courses.name: History of the Designed Environment to 1750
courses.description: An in-depth study of the designed environment including interiors, architecture, art, and the decorative arts within the major historical periods and cultural context from prehistory to the Industrial Revolution.

courses.name: Design Precedents: Architecture, Interiors and Furniture since the Industrial Revolution
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ARCHST 7440). Analysis of historical exemplars of architecture, interiors and furniture design offering strategies for approaching contemporary design problems.  Covers design precedents from industrial revolution to contemporary design.

courses.name: Visual Presentation for Design
courses.description: Emphasizes principles and techniques for effective visual design presentation.  Focuses on concepts of design, layout, storytelling, critiques, and hands on exercise.

courses.name: Recent Trends
courses.description: Upper-division students seeking additional knowledge in specific subject matter areas including digital media software.

courses.name: Shaping Human Settlements
courses.description: Review classic designs and designers, key concepts and enduring issues of community design within the overall framework of environmental design.

courses.name: Housing Concepts and Issues
courses.description: Evaluate housing policies, regulations, codes, programs; global and ecological perspectives of environment and behavior; historic preservation; financial issues; trends and projections.

courses.name: Place-Making in Community Design
courses.description: Ideologies, case studies and participatory methods on place-making in community design.  Use processes to design a place-making scheme in actual community project.

courses.name: Design Business Practices
courses.description: Analysis of the basic professional, human, and business skills necessary for the successful design practice.

courses.name: Healthcare Facilities Design
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ARCHST 7760). Health care facilities design and planning course provides an in-depth investigation of best practice examples. Design and research methods include evidence-based design, simulation, and space syntax analysis leading to high-performance healthcare design.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Interiors Studio III
courses.description: Spatial morphology, organization pattern, construction methods, materials, systems, and processes and integration with total design processes. Space planning and spatial manipulation in response to social, environmental, functional, and aesthetics specific to interiors.

courses.name: Interiors Studio IV
courses.description: Continuation of ARCHST 4813. Manipulation of form and space responding to programmatic functions and activities, and constraints imposed by structure, building materials, spatial enclosure, and related factors. Projects may involve designing single-function space to multiple-function layered spaces--both vertically and horizontally.

courses.name: Construction Documents and Building Information Modeling Studio
courses.description: Studio of how materials, systems, and assemblies reinforce and extend intentions of designers. Course teaches strategies and techniques for integration and coordination of the building components and details in construction documents and building information modeling.

courses.name: Architectural Studio III
courses.description: Continuation of  ARCHST 3182.  Spatial morphology, organization pattern, construction methods, materials, systems, and processes and integration with total design process.  Space planning and spatial manipulation in response to social, environmental, functional, and aesthetics specifics to architecture.

courses.name: Architectural Studio IV
courses.description: Continuation of  ARCHST 4823.  Manipulation of form and space responding to programmatic functions and activities, and constraints imposed by structure, building materials, spatial enclosure, and related factors.  Projects may involve designing single-function space to multiple-function layered spaces - both vertically and horizontally.

courses.name: Programming for Thesis Design Studio
courses.description: Develop written comprehensive program for thesis design studio project. Supervised by student-selected committee -- one departmental thesis advisor and at least one additional faculty member.

courses.name: Internship in Environmental Design
courses.description: Field experience in design under professional and educational supervision.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Readings in Architectural Studio
courses.description: Readings in recent research materials.

courses.name: Design Research and Service Design
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ARCHST 7961). Provides an overview of applied research methods for design and development of products, services and environments.  Introduces human-centered approach to design research and Communication of research findings to informed design concepts.

courses.name: Information Visualization and Visual Analytics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ARCHST 7962). Foundation for information visualization and deals with external representation and interactive manipulation of information, data or artifacts using digital tools to enhance communication, analytical reasoning and decision-making.

courses.name: Human Factors Research for Design
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ARCHST 7963). Investigate effect of people's physical psychological, social functions in environments of differing scales.  Use research techniques of photo-interviewers, mapping, and user analysis to develop an appropriate program for redesign.

courses.name: Design Thinking and Creative Process
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ARCHST 7964). Analysis of how designers think, solve design problems, and engage in the creative process.  Includes design methods, design cognition computations, and design protocol studies.

courses.name: Thesis Design Studio
courses.description: Capstone experience on a single comprehensive project. Objective is to enable synthesis of previous course work by addressing a design problem defined in  ARCHST 4860.

courses.name: Topics in Environmental Design
courses.description: Selected current topics in field of interest.

courses.name: Problems in Environmental Design
courses.description: Supervised independent work.
courses.prerequisites: 3000-level course in field of problem  and instructor's consent

courses.name: Allied Architecture and Urban Design
courses.description: Overview of the built environment in relation to architecture and allied design.  Emphasis on architecture, interior, landscape and urban design studies.

courses.name: Computer Graphic Application for Design I
courses.description: Applications of computer graphics for design and art; includes visualization, animation and creative development. May repeat up to 12 credit hours maximum.

courses.name: Graduate Design Communication I
courses.description: Studio course in techniques and conventions of graphic communication as an aid in the design process of built forms.

courses.name: Graduate Building Systems
courses.description: Integrated building systems; structure construction, technology, comfort; including voice-communications, safety, floor, wall, ceiling, mechanical, electrical, and plumbing systems, project estimating and management.

courses.name: Graduate Systems Laboratory
courses.description: Experimental learning setting involving building construction systems, renovation, materials and finishes testing and experimentation. Focus on hands-on opportunities investigating building technology properties in detail. Laboratory 3 hrs/week.

courses.name: Materials, Methods and Products
courses.description: Inherent qualities of materials used in the design of interior environments. Manufacturing, application, and installation methods. Focus on environmentally sensitive materials.

courses.name: Sustainable Technologies and Systems
courses.description: An in-depth study of ecologically-sensitive and energy-efficient strategies used in buildings and interiors.

courses.name: Energy-Efficient Building Design
courses.description: This course is a broad study of energy use and energy-efficient strategies for buildings.  The course will cover the fundamentals of climate-based design, energy-efficient heating/cooling/daylighting strategies, alternative energy systems applicable to buildings, energy auditing/modeling/verification, applicable building energy codes, and high performance building technologies. Recommended for graduate students with undergraduate degrees and experience in engineering, architecture, and/or building science.

courses.name: Compliance and Specifications
courses.description: Application of laws, codes, regulations, standards in specifying for life safety, barrier-free and universal design, lighting, human factors, and contract documents.

courses.name: Recent Trends in Digital Media I
courses.description: Recent Trends in Digital Media I

courses.name: History of the Designed Environment to 1750
courses.description: An in-depth study of the designed environment including housing interiors, and furniture of the major historical periods from prehistory to the Industrial Revolution.

courses.name: Study Abroad in Architectural History
courses.description: Discovery of historic architecture through on-site tour of timeless cities and places.  May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: History of the Designed Environment after 1750
courses.description: An in-depth study of the designed environment, including housing, interiors, and furniture of the major historical periods from the Industrial Revolution to today.

courses.name: Guiding Design with Historic Preservation
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ARCHST 4430). Approaches to historic preservation; historic roots of architecture and interiors; regulations and design guidelines governing intervention; assessing significance of historic properties.
courses.prerequisites: American History or Government or Art History or instructor's consent

courses.name: Design Precedents: Architecture, Interiors and Furniture since the Industrial Revolution
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ARCHST 4440). Analysis of historical exemplars of architecture, interiors and furniture design offering strategies for approaching contemporary design problems.  Covers design precedents from industrial revolution to contemporary design.

courses.name: Visual Presentation for Design
courses.description: Emphasizes principles and techniques for effective visual design presentation.  Focuses on concepts of design, layout storytelling, critiques and hands on exercises.

courses.name: Recent Trends in Environmental Design
courses.description: Upper-division students seeking additional knowledge in specific subject matter areas including digital media software.

courses.name: Environment and Behavior
courses.description: Evaluate relationships between human behavior and environmental design. Survey of environment and behavior theoretical foundations examining how these concepts translate into a more responsive theory of design.

courses.name: Shaping Human Settlements
courses.description: Review classic designs and designers, key concepts and enduring issues of community design within the overall framework of environmental design.

courses.name: Physical Function and Older Adults
courses.description: (same as F_C_MD 7750, HMI 7750, H_D_FS 7750, NURSE 7750, P_HLTH 7750, and SOC_WK 7752).  This course takes an interdisciplinary approach to understanding and improving the physical function and independence of older adults and explores approaches to alleviate disabling conditions that interfere with physical function and quality of life in old age.   Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Psychosocial Function and Older Adults
courses.description: (same as F_C_MD 7751,HMI 7751, H_D_FS 7751, NURSE 7751, P_HLTH 7751 and SOC_WK 7751).  This course takes an Interdisciplinary approach to understanding the psychosocial function of older adults and explores approaches to alleviate disabling conditions that interfere with psychosocial function and quality of life in old age.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Housing Concepts and Issues
courses.description: Evaluate housing policies, regulations, codes, programs; global and ecological perspectives of environment and behavior; historic preservation; financial issues; trends and projections.

courses.name: Place-Making in Community Design
courses.description: Ideologies, case studies and participatory methods on place-making in community design.  Use processes to design a place-making scheme in actual community project.

courses.name: Design Business Practices
courses.description: Analysis of the basic professional, human, and business skills necessary for the successful design practice. Prerequisites or Corequisites of Studio IV and anticipated graduation during final academic year.

courses.name: Healthcare Facilities Design
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ARCHST 4760). Health care facilities design and planning course provides an in-depth investigation of best practice examples. Design and research methods include evidence-based design, simulation, and space syntax analysis leading to high-performance healthcare design. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Studio V
courses.description: A continuation of previous studio with emphasis on digital media.

courses.name: Graduate Design Studio
courses.description: Advanced graduate level design experience emphasizing project complexity, design skill refinement, and optional development of thesis project strategies.

courses.name: Internship in Environmental Design
courses.description: Field experience in design under professional and educational supervision.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Readings in Environmental Design
courses.description: Readings in recent research materials.

courses.name: Design Research and Service Design
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ARCHST 4961). Provides an overview of applied research methods for design and development of products, services and environments. Introduces human-centered approach to design research and communication of research findings to inform design concepts.

courses.name: Information Visualization and Visual Analytics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ARCHST 4962). Foundation for information visualization and deals with external representation and interactive manipulation of information, data or artifacts using digital tools to enhance communication, analytical reasoning and decision-making.

courses.name: Human Factors Research for Design
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ARCHST 4963). Investigate effect of people's physical psychological, social functions in environments of differing scales.  Use research techniques of photo-interviewers, mapping, and user analysis to develop an appropriate program for redesign.

courses.name: Design Thinking and Creative Process
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ARCHST 4964). Analysis of how designers think, solve design problems, and engage in the creative process. Includes design methods, design cognition and computations, and design protocol studies.

courses.name: Topics in Environmental Design
courses.description: Selected current topics in field of interest.

courses.name: Research Methods in Environmental Design
courses.description: A comparative study of quantitative and qualitative methods in environmental design with emphasis on research results and analyses. Lectures and seminar discussions.

courses.name: Problems in Environmental Design
courses.prerequisites: 4000-level course in field of problem and instructor's consent

courses.name: Master's Research in Environmental Design
courses.description: Independent research leading to a creative project.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Computer Graphic Application for Design II
courses.description: Creative computer graphic modeling, rendering and animation projects related to the academic background and interests of individual students. May be repeated to 6 hours maximum.

courses.name: Graduate Design Communication II
courses.description: Advanced studio in techniques and conventions of graphic communication as aides in the design process.

courses.name: Graduate Environmental Analysis
courses.description: Analysis of design principles and organizational factors operating in a building by means of dissection. Volumetric disposition, circulation pattern, axes, structural system, materials, purpose, and symbolism.

courses.name: Philosophy of Environmental Design Research
courses.description: Formal environmental design theory concerning historical precedents, current aesthetic trends, and design processes. Assignments investigate philosophical influences, architectonic vocabularies, and communication of idea and artifact. May be repeated up to 12 credit hours.

courses.name: Theoretical Perspectives of Design Computing
courses.description: Key theoretical ideas underlying the relationship between design and computing. Main research topics relevant to current discourse in design computing.

courses.name: Theories in Architectural and Interior Design
courses.description: Architectural and interior design theory is explored as a field of inquiry.  Students become familiar with a theoretical framework that is sensitive to the play between the principles of a building (what it is as a design) and the circumstances of a building (what it becomes to be).

courses.name: Graduate Digital Design Studio
courses.description: Graduate level design experience emphasizing project complexity, design skill refinement, and use of digital media for design representation.

courses.name: Digital Design Studio II
courses.description: Advanced graduate level design experience emphasizing design, documentation, and representation using digital media. Optional development of graduate thesis project may be scheduled in this studio.

courses.name: Graduate Design Studio
courses.description: Advanced graduate level design experience emphasizing project complexity, design skill refinement, and optional development of thesis project strategies.

courses.name: Seminar in Environmental Design
courses.description: Reports, discussion of recent work in area of concentration.

courses.name: Environment and Behavior II
courses.description: Synthesis of environment and behavior themes in design research and application to professional practice. Research on socio-behavioral phenomena, user groups, places. Emphasis on integrated interactive character of elements.

courses.name: Qualitative Research Methods
courses.description: Explores qualitative research methods as foundation for subsequent study. Focuses on qualitative research of the built environment.  Course may be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Readings in Environmental Design
courses.description: Readings in recent research materials.

courses.name: Thesis Project Proposal
courses.description: The formal opportunity to express the intent and scope of the thesis project.

courses.name: Topics in Environmental Design
courses.description: Selected current topics in field of interest.

courses.name: Problems in Environmental Design
courses.prerequisites: 4000-level course in field of problem and instructor's consent

courses.name: Doctoral Research in Environmental Design
courses.description: Independent research leading to thesis or dissertation. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Recent Trends in Environmental Design
courses.description: For students seeking additional knowledge and understanding in specific subject matter areas.

courses.name: Dissertation Proposal
courses.description: A formal dissertation proposal is written and presented to the dissertation committee for approval.

courses.name: Pilot Project for Dissertation
courses.description: Working with advisor, student proposes, conducts, and reports the findings from a pilot study germane to the dissertation topic in preparation for the dissertation research.
